captions.text: [ Music ]

>> [Background Music] [Singing]
You don't know why I lie.
You know why I cry.
You don't know how I came up.
You don't know what I learned.

You don't know how I hurt,
never lived where I grew up,

but now I'm the boss,
talking about Boss Lady.

Now I'm the boss,
talking about Boss Lady.

>> The lighting is
terrible, bad angles.
Look at this.
Who designed our wardrobe?

Look at her; has
she gained weight?
No, this will not work.
I can't use any of that.

Tell the photographer and the
wardrobe stylist they're fired.

Matter of fact, fire
the models, too.

>> Okay. Fire the
photographers, the models,
and the wardrobe stylist.
Got it.
>> What time is Faye?
>> Ooh, its 4:59, ma'am.
>> Oh, good, I can't wait to get

on that plane and
get out of here.

I need a break from
all this stupidity.

>> Ooh, ooh, before you go
Mrs. Graves, you still have

to answer those investigative
news reports regarding marketing

your liquor line to
inner city youth.
>> And my vacation?

>> All of your bags are
packed and waiting for you
on your private plane.

>> [Multiple speakers]: Well, to
answer the marketing questions,

thank you for making us
aware of this problem.

Your concerns are
the upmost importance
to Gravedigger Records.
We will work intently...

>> ...to resolve the issue
with urgency [laughter].

>> And Betty, make sure
my masseuse is ready
for me as soon as we land.

Tell the concierge I want
-- what is that man's name?
>> Jose.

>> Jose. My hot Latin
lover and just what I need
to relieve some of this stress.
>> Ahh, yeah [singing].

>> Betty, come on,
pay attention, focus.
>> Sorry, yes ma'am.

Tell them she wants
Jose, got it.

>> Ms. Graves, there's
someone here to see you.

>> Ryan, you idiot,
can you tell time?

Its 5 o'clock, the
office is closed.

>> Ma'am, ma'am, ma'am,
you can't go in there.
>> Roxanne, what is this?

You can't keep treating
me like this.
>> Oh no, no, no, no, Ms. Gail.

It is 5 o'clock and
the office is closed.

>> Girl, [laughter] you
better shut your mouth

and keep shuffling them
papers before I shuffle you.
Go sit down.
>> Yes, ma'am.

>> Have you lost your
mind coming in my office

after hours acting like
some ghetto hood rat?
>> We need to talk.
Now!

>> $37? What is this, I
mean how am I supposed

to live off of $37,
Roxanne, huh?

>> Yeah, that's $37
[laughter and snorting].
>> That's what it says, $37.
>> It's what you earned.

Come on now, Gail, you haven't
had a hit in what, seven years?

In this business, that
makes you retired.

>> You know what,
I am not a fool.

I know you licensed my song on
that new movie, so don't tell me
that that was only worth $37.

>> And what makes you think
I owe you anything for that?

I own 100% of the
mechanical rights.
I mean really, you people need

to start reading your
contracts better.
>> When, please tell me when,

have you ever written
anything for anybody?

Huh? All you do is live off
of other people's talent.
>> Excuse me?

>> Yeah, I think you
heard me the first time.
>> Uh-oh.
>> I made you, Gail.

You were nothing and
I made you a star.
Now, since you're working

for the good old church now
[laughter], let them pay you.

You made your choice and now
you see without Roxanne Graves,

why [laughter] you're just
a mediocre choir member
with a dream.
Now get out my office.

>> Bye, Ms. Gail,
have a nice day.
>> Ooh, oh.
>> You're going to rot in Hell.
You don't have a soul.
>> [Inaudible] $37, really?
>> Ryan. Ryan.

>> Yeah, I'm going to need you
to write me another check, okay,

in the name of Jesus,
amen, okay.

I'm going to need you to
write me another check.
I need you.

I'm Gail Johnson, Gail
Johnson, Gail Johnson.

$37, what am I supposed
to do with $37 [yelling]?

>> When you signed a
deal with Gravedigger,
you signed over your soul.

I own you and don't
you ever forget it.

>> [Crying] You can't treat
people like this, Roxanne.

Don't you know that all this
is going to come back on you?
Aren't you afraid?

>> [Background crying]
Afraid of what?

I'm not afraid of anything
except for losing my net worth

and believe me, that ain't
ever going to happen.
[ Crying and Choking ]

Now, if you come at
me like that again ...
>> [Crying] Please ...
>> I'll kill you myself.
You understand me?
>> [Crying] Yes, sorry, please.

>> Now if you want to
discuss this matter further,
what are my hours of operation?

[Audience laughter]
Come on, say it with me.
>> [Crying] 9:00 to 5:00.
>> Good girl.

Cancel this check;
I'll buy me a new one.

>> Ryan, what are
you doing, Ryan.
It's me, Gail, Gail Johnson.

Wait a minute, I'm Gail, you
all can't treat me like this.
[Inaudible].
>> Get this trash out my office.
>> Let me go.
I hate you, you evil witch.
>> [Background screaming] Oh,

now that's not very
Christianly, Gail.
Don't forget your $37 check.

Buy you something
good at Walmart.

You know what I am so tired of
this ungratefulness around here.
>> Alrighty then.

Ms. Gail, this -- this
telegram came for you.

It says it's urgent and it's
from your hometown, Detroit.
>> Detroit?
>> Yes, ma'am.
Well, gotta go.
Toodles. Adios.
Hasta Luego.
Good-bye.
>> Ryan. What is this all about?

[Whispering] What's
this all about?

[Loud voice] Sweep the building
and make sure everyone's gone.

Then tell my driver I'll be
down in about 30 minutes.
Now leave, I want to be alone.
Now! [Inaudible] idiot.
What is this all about?
[ Background Sounds ]
>> Roxanne.
Please don't leave me, Roxanne.
Don't let them take me.

>> Okay, you have to keep
it together, Roxanne.

[Pills rattling]
Take these pills.
I'm good. I'm good.
Let me get out of here.
[Inaudible].
[ Background Sounds ]

What part of sweep the building
and leave, don't you understand?

Really, I mean you're
such an idiot.

You would think after
working for me for 10 years,

your job performance
would have improved.
You know what, you're fired.

Get out. Okay, I don't think
you heard me the first time.
I said you're fired.
>> Not so fast, Boss Lady.
>> Ryan, put that down.
Put it down.
What are you doing?
What is this, some type of joke?
>> Small fry.

[Laughter] What's the matter,
you're not happy to see me?

>> I bet you thought
this was one face
that you would never see again.
>> [Screaming] Betty, help.

>> [Laughter] Doesn't feel
so good when the shoe's
on the other foot now does it?

Bryan, my man, good
to see you again, bro.
>> Same here, bro.

>> Like what you're doing,
but I can take it from here.
Hey, but do me one favor.

Why don't you wait outside
for me, and if you see so much

as her toe come through that
door, I want you to blow her
to kingdom come, you got me man?

>> I got you, dog, my
pleasure [laughter].
[ Music ]
>> What you doin' here?
I thought you were dead.
>> Dead? Yeah, I'm sure you did.

But as you can see, its Jowan
Towers right here in the flesh

and I've come back
to get what's mine.
>> What you mean, what's yours?
>> This -- all this is mine.

You built this place
off the blood, sweat,

and tears of people's hopes,
people's dreams, and you --

you took it all from them, but
it's payback time [laughter].
>> Payback for what?
I don't owe you anything.

>> [Background Music]
You don't owe me?

You let me rot in that jail
for 15 years, Roxanne, 15 years
and what did I get in return?
Did I get a visit?
Did I get one letter?
Did you answer any of my calls?

And with all this you gots, I
couldn't even get $10 for a bar

of soap to wash my
behind, nothing.

>> Look, Jowan, you
got it all wrong.
You got it all wrong [laughter].

>> [Background Music] No
fool, you've got it wrong,
but I'm about to get mine.

Oh yeah, everything you owe me,
I'm about to get mine and from

where I'm standing,
that's everything.
>> Over my dead body.
>> [Laughter] So be it.
Roxanne Graves.
Man, it's going to feel so good

to see you get what's
finally coming to you.

>> Don't stand there and
act like you're innocent.
You know what?
[Screaming]
>> Innocent.

It seems to me you've
got a little amnesia.
>> Okay. Okay.
Okay. Okay.

>> [Background Music]
Because I was innocent
until I met your family.

Your family corrupted
the entire neighborhood,

the entire neighborhood and
all I wanted to do was go
to art school, remember?
[ Music ]
>> Good morning, Ms. Williams.
>> Good morning.
>> Watch this Sarah, do this.

Come on. No, not like
that -- do it this way.
Come on.

>> [Background Music]
Roxanne, you're so [inaudible].

>> Roxanne, cut all
that racket down.

You're making enough
noise to wake up the dead.

>> Sorry, Ms. Margaret, I was
just showing Sarah this routine
for the school talent show.
>> Talent show?

I didn't know you
could sing or dance.

>> [Background Music] No, Ms.
Margaret, the song isn't for me.
It's for my friend Shaquanda

to help her win the
school talent show.

I don't really want to be
a singer, Ms. Margaret.

I want to have my own record
company just like Motown.

>> Wow, them some big
ambitions for a little girl,

but if you put your mind
to it, you can do anything.

Just promise me when
you make it big,

you won't forget
about Ms. Margaret.
>> I won't, Ms. Margaret.
>> Hey there, Sarah.

>> Aren't you going
to say something?

What's wrong with
her, Ms. Margaret?

How come she don't
ever say anything?

I mean she my little sister,
but she doesn't even talk to me.

You know, they put her
in those special classes
at school, Ms. Margaret.
>> Huh-huh-huh.
Stop right there.

Now listen, Sarah just has a
different way of communicating,

that's all and what
about you, young lady,

why aren't you dressed
for school?

>> Mama say I need to help
her around the house today.
She's not feeling so good.
>> More like hung over.
Listen here, you hungry baby?

>> A little bit, but I have
to walk Sarah to school

and she's going to
eat breakfast there.

>> Well, after you walk
Sarah to school, come on back

because I've got some fried
chicken, rice and gravy,

candied yams, string
beans, cornbread,
and a little apple cobbler

for my plant deliveries
down at Chrysler.

[Laughter] I'll have
a plate waiting
for you, all right, baby?
>> Thanks, Ms. Margaret.
>> You're welcome, baby.

>> Next time you want
to invite my daughter

to breakfast you need
to check with me first.

>> Who and you need
to spray for fleas.

>> Hey, what [audience
laughter]...

>> Don't talk to Ms.
Margaret like that.
>> Who you think you talking to?

Don't you fast-talk me;
I'm still your mother.
Show some respect.

Anyway, I need you to come in
here and do something for me.

>> Well, I just have to
take Sarah to school first.
I'll just be a minute, okay?

>> My friend David here can walk
her; you just come in the house.

>> Why, so he can give her a
black eye like he gave you?

I'll take her to school, mom,
and I'll just be a minute.

>> You know what, you
got one more time,

you hear me Roxie,
one more time.

I'm so sick of that
mouth of yours.
Sarah, come here.
[Audience laughter] Come here.
[ Pause ]
Hurry up.
[ Audience Laughter ]

>> Small fry, why
you still here?
You not going to school again?

>> My mama said I
need to stay home
and help her around the house.
>> I can't stand your mama.
>> Don't talk about my mama.
Where you going?

>> Duh, the same
place I go every day.
>> To take them dinners?

>> Yeah man, them
fools be acting

like they starving
down at the plant.
>> [Laughter] Ah, man.

Guess we both helping
our mamas today, huh?
>> Oh, it's all good for now.
Guess what.
>> What?

>> I'm really going to
art school in the fall.
>> You really going?

>> Yes. [Laughter] Remember
that drawing I submitted?
>> Yeah, the one you showed me.
>> They accepted it.
>> Did they?
>> I told you.
>> They did?
I knew it.
I told you it was good.
I told him it was good.

>> Just call me the
Da Vinci of Detroit.
[Laughter] Guess what.
>> What?

>> I'm going to get a
part-time job this summer

because I just found out
that they hiring a part-time
down at Technicolor.
>> Really?
>> Get in the house.

>> I just have to take Sarah
to school mom, I'll be back.

>> Roxie, wait up, I'm going
to walk to school with you.
Wait up.
>> Well good morning, Debra.
>> Good morning, Ms. Margaret.
>> Is everything okay, Debra?
>> Everything is all right,

I just need to take my
insulin, that's all.
My blood sugar a little high.

>> Oh, something high all
right, but I don't know

about no blood sugar
[audience laughter].
>> What was that, Margaret?

>> I said, "Check your nose,
baby, you got a booger."
[Audience laughter] Listen here.

That landlord been coming
around here looking for you

and I can't keep
covering for you, Debra.

You going to have to pay
your rent or get evicted.

>> Look, look, just tell him
-- next time he come by here,

just tell him I'll pay him
by the end of the week, okay?

>> And just how do you
propose to do that?

>> Why you always in
my business, Margaret?
We fine over here, okay?

I'll get the money,
how I get the money.
I'm so sick of you judging me.

>> Baby, I'm not judging
you, but at a certain point

in your life, you're going
to have to do what's best
for you and those girls.

I think one of the reasons why
Sarah's so afraid to talk is

because you always yelling
at her, or you got a man
over here every other day.

>> What? You mad because
ain't nobody coming
over here to check on you?

Look, I take good care
of my girls, good care,

I mean especially for someone
who was raised in a foster home

and only had a ninth
grade education.
I ain't got many options.
>> Oh baby, you got options.
We all have options.

See, when my man ran out on me
for that heifer in the projects

with them six kids by
five different daddies,

[audience laughter] I
started my catering business.

Even though he was
paying the bills,

I refuse to let it destroy me
and become another statistic

because when you know
better, you do better.

Now you chew on that, I'm
going to go get these beans on.
[ Pause ]
>> Roxanne, baby.
Roxanne, come here, baby.
[ Music ]

>> [Background Music]
Mama, mama,
please can you get someone else.

>> Quit acting like a
little baby now, come on,

I need someone [inaudible]
insulin.

>> Mama, but you -- mama you
said we wasn't gone do this no
more, ma.

>> Come on with you
-- come here.
Come here.
[ Music ]
>> Come here.
[ Music ]
>> You love me?
>> Yes.

>> [Background Music]
If you love me,
do what I say, help me, please.
[ Music ]
>> Good girl.
Good girl.
[ Music ]
>> Why you ain't in school?

>> Because you told me to
stay here and help you.
>> You helped me, all right.

Go on finish the rest of your
classes; play with Sarah,
whatever it is you do.
I really don't care.

>> [Background Music]
Sarah baby, its okay.
It's going to be okay.
You hear Ms. Margaret?
It's going to be okay, baby.
Lord Jesus, help this child.
>> Hey look, don't mess this up.

The armored truck's
coming around 11:15.

As long as you do what
you supposed to do,
everything should go smooth.
If you don't have all my money

after tonight, I'm
gone kill you.
You understand me?

>> No, I -- I got you
Ty; I got you, we good.
>> All right.

Go on head and get up
out of here and hey,
tell Auntie Linda I said hi.
>> Okay, boss.

>> Tyrone, Tyrone, still running
things in the hood, I see?

>> Yeah, well if it ain't
one hit wonder Sylvester.

What brings you down here
to all the common folk?

>> You know, I'm the
landlord, Tyrone and word

on the street is you've
been dealing out this store

and if that's true, you
cutting into my territory.
>> Dealing?

I don't even get down like
that, man, and you know it.
>> Yeah, okay.

Let's just have this
conversation in a few minutes.
I'll be back, Tyrone.
>> Yeah. I'll be here.
>> Don't go nowhere.
This my block.
[ Background Sounds ]

>> Jowan, what's going on
young blood, you all right?
>> Tyrone ...

>> You still in the
delivery business?
>> Huh?
>> What you got there?

>> Delivery business
going good, man, you know?

Just helping out my mama,
it's a family thing.

You know I'm going to
art school in the fall.
>> Oh, okay.
>> Yeah.
>> What's up, man.

Look, you a smart young cat, got
a good head on your shoulders.
>> Thanks.

>> I could use a book smart
cat like you on my team.

>> Look man, I appreciate
the offer man,

but I don't get down
like that, man.
I'm not into drugs.
>> Drugs?
>> Yeah.

>> Boy, who said
anything about drugs?
I'm a businessman.
I got land, investments.
I'm making mines work for me.

You need to come on
over here and get
with this franchise [laughter].

>> Look Ty, I'm good
man, all right?

>> You good, huh
[audience laughter]?
>> Ooh. What's that?

>> More money than you've ever
seen in your life, ain't it boy?
>> Yeah.
>> Hmm, tell you what.

I got a little job to
do around 7:30 tonight.

Why don't you come see me,
it's at a jewelry store.
All I need you to do is drive.
Huh, here's a down payment.

>> I don't know if
I can do this, Ty.
>> Hey, listen.
You try it once.

If you don't like it, you
free to go your own way.
>>Okay.
>> But Jowan ...
>> Huh?
>> If you bite off that apple

after today, just
know I own you.
>> Okay.
>> All right?
>> Yep. Yep.
>> All right, 7:30, all right?
>> 7:30, man.
>> Nice doin' business with you.

>> [Inaudible] what
took you so long?
>> What's up small fry?

I was just at the store
talking to Tyrone.
>> Oh, the store's open?
Cool, I need [inaudible].
>> What's up?

>> [Inaudible] why
you looking' sad?

>> Nothin', small fry, I just
got a lot on my mind, all right?

You too young to
understand any way.
>> I understand a lot.

>> Look, I'm going to go
in the house, all right,
because I got a date with Sheila

from around the corner
[laughter].
>> Sheila?
>> Yeah.

>> Sheila from around
the corner?
Sheila don't want you, buster.
>> Girl. Yo mama.
>> Don't talk about my mama.

>> Yo mama, son, you better
get your narrow behind
in here and give me my money.
>> Yes, ma'am.
>> [Laughter] Hey daddy.
>> Hey, baby girl.
How's daddy's girl doing?

>> Good. Where you
been at, daddy?

>> Hey, I'm the adult; I ask
the questions around here.

Now what I want to
know is why you ain't
in school, baby girl, huh?

>> Mama wasn't feeling
good today.

She asked me to stay home to
help her around the house.

>> Is your mama on
that stuff again?

Huh? Is she feeding you, baby
girl or is she still running

around here selling
her food stamps?
>> I'm eating daddy.

Ms. Margaret makes sure me
and Sarah eat every day.
>> That's your mama's job.

Here, why don't you
take a few dollars

and get yourself
something to eat, all right?
>> Okay.

>> Make sure you look after
your little sister, too.
>> All right, thank you, daddy.

>> Listen, you're 12
years old now, all right.

I don't have time to
sit around and baby you.

When I was 12 years
old, I did my first job.

Now I know you love your
mama, but your mama's a junkie
and you can't trust her.

I don't care if she in your
family or not, all right?
>> Okay, dad.
>> All right baby girl.
>> Tyrone.
Tyrone, [inaudible] [laughter].
>> Speaking of the devil.

Look, baby girl, go in
the store for a minute,
watch the store for daddy.
[ Background Sounds ]

>> Girl, what's wrong
with you, are you zooted?
>> No.

>> You smell like
old fish grease.

When's the last time
you took a bath?
>> Aren't you happy to see me?

>> Not looking like the
wicked witch of the Westside.

You need to get in there
and clean yourself up

and start making
sure my baby eats.

Somebody gone call
the people on you.

>> Forget you, Tyrone,
forget you.
I don't need you.
>> Oh, forget me?
>> Yes.
>> Okay, forget me.
>> Ty. Ty, baby, wait.
>> No, no, no.
>> Ty wait.

Look, I'm a little
short on my rent.

Can you just give me a little
something until the end
of this week or something?

>> Why, so you can
go shoot it up?
>> No, no, no.
Look, look, baby, what's up?

Look why don't you
come in side, huh?

Let me take care of you,
make you feel real good.

>> Look, don't you ever come
on me like that, you hear me?

[Screaming] Don't you
ever come on me like that.

Now I'll take care of the
landlord and it's only
because you've got my baby girl.

But its the last time,
Deb, and I mean it.
I'm warning you.

>> Hey dad, I gotta go get
Sarah from school, okay?

>> Yeah, all right,
be safe, all right.
>> All right, bye daddy.

>> Debra Graves, it's
been a long time.

>> Yeah, it's been
three years to be exact.

When you going to help me
out with your daughter?

Your daughter Sarah,
remember her?

>> That girl don't look nothing
like me [audience laughter].

>> What, are you --
Sylvester wait, listen, wait.
>> I'm out of here.

>> Sylvester, look, I'm a
little short on my rent,

can you help me and give
me a little something?

>> Who do I look like, I
run a charity business?

>> I ain't askin'
you for charity.
I can definitely pay you.

It'd be well worth
every penny, I promise.

>> I guess I'm giving
donations today.
>> Okay.
[ Audience Laughter ]
>> Hey, J, what's wrong?

You've been looking
tore up all day.
Sheila must have dumped you.
>> What? Girl, please.

[Laughter] And dump
all this sexiness?

[Audience laughter]
Actually, small fry,

it really ain't got
nothing to do with Sheila.

The art school sent me a
letter saying that they going

to give me a scholarship
to go to school,

but now it's only partial,
which means I've got to come

up with $2,000 for
the whole year.

>> Where you gone get
that kind of money, J?
>> I don't know.

>> Where the heck
is this fool at?
>> Here you go, Ty.
Nice doing business with you.
>> Hey, hey, hey, come here.
Where's the rest of my money?
This ain't all my money.
>> It's all there, Ty.

>> Didn't I tell you the next
time you ain't have all my money
I was going to kill you?

>> Count it again,
Ty, it's there.
>> Count it again, huh?
>> Yeah
>> [Background Music] Look,

didn't I tell you next time you
ain't have all my money I was
going to kill you, huh?

Now you got until 10 o'clock
to have the rest of my money

or you might as well
go buy your mama

that little black
dress, you hear me?
>> Brian, take this trash out.

>> Come on John hold on
let me fix this, John.

>> [Background Music] Small fry,
I think I know how I'm going
to get the art school money.
Go in the house, all right?
I'll be back [footsteps].
>> Jowan, my man, right on time.

Come on let me holler
at you for a minute.

>> You're trying to make it
seem like my daddy forced you.
No Jowan, you had a choice.

>> [Background Music] And
what choice did I have?

It was either do what Tyrone
said or suffer the consequences.
I had dreams, big dreams.

I was going to be the
first kid out the hood

with my own art gallery,
but hey,
thanks to my best friend ...
>> Oh, so that's my fault.
>> Whose fault is it?

>> No Jowan that was
over 25 years ago.
You can't change the past.
What's done is done.

>> [Background Music] No,
you can't change the past
but you can make a right future.

And that's exactly what I'm
here to do, make things right,

even the score, balance
the scales.

See you have done a lot of
people wrong in your life Rox,

a lot of people and your owe
people but you don't owe anybody
as much as you owe me.

>> You're weak, always
weak, always [inaudible].
>> Oh yeah.
>> Well guess what Jowan?

You can't have any of
this or anything of mine.
I earned this.
